AN HISTORIC FIGHT.

House of Lords at Last Consents to Legalise Marriage With a Deaf Person.

After an agitation extended through the length and breadth of the British House of Lords has been carried on for many years in regard to allowing marriages with a deaf-mute wife, it was decided by the House of Lords that there should be no legal impediment to such marriages where legal consent is given by both parties. As a result such marriages were legalised by the Act of Parliament which came into force on the same day that the marriage was solemnised.

The case of Henry VIII.

A history of the subject dates back to the reign of Henry VIII., who was peculiarly qualified as an authority on the subject. He had a son named Richard, but in 1579 such a union was declared illegal under the Statute of Wills. This was Lord Hardwicke's Act, which was passed in 1754, and which declared legal, but incestuous marriages, those between cousins, and marriages between persons of the same degree of consanguinity. It was not until the next session of Parliament that the question of marriages between persons of the same degree of consanguinity was raised again, and Lord Hardwicke refused to interfere.

In 1841 Lord Thurlow introduced a Bill to allow marriages between persons of the same degree of consanguinity. In the next year the Commons defeated a similar measure, and in 1843 a Royal Commission was appointed to consider the question. In 1844 the result was another bill, introduced by Lord Hardwicke, which was again defeated. Next year it was passed in the Commons, but it was again rejected in the Lords, and it was again rejected in the Commons. Since then the measure has been introduced several times, but always the Lords have refused to pass it.

SOME HISTORY AND PIONEER EXPERIENCES OF
HEWARD, SASK. FROM ITS SETTLEMENT IN
1900 TO 1914

BY
GEORGE A HARRIS,
VANCOUVER, B.C.
JULY 1925.
In the summer of 1900, perhaps in May, William Irvin and Hamilton Caldwell filed on homestead Sec. 22-9-9-W-8, in this area. These two fellows met in Winnipeg on their way to take up land on the prairie. Bill came from Owen Sound, Ont. and Ham from Central Ireland. Heward village now stands on the land originally owned by Mr. Caldwell. While preparing to build their small house and a stable they met a Frenchman who had come to homestead too, but finally got disgusted with the country, he decided he would go back to where he came from, he had four horses and a wagon with some agriculture implements. Bill and Ham bought his whole outfit and started farming, they also bought a fine yoke of oxen from a farmer in the French Settlement near Moose Mountain Creek.

Mr. William McKenzie and wife and three children came too, that spring, he came from near Portage La Prairie and farmed a whole section a little south of where Heward now stands. Herb Fox and wife were the second couple to bring wives and George McCurdy the third. Herb and wife came from Rapinka, Man., George and wife and son John came from Wingham, Ontario. James and Frank Andrews also came that spring, coming in a covered wagon from Kansas, U.S.A., but they located about six miles North West. These people, as far as I can remember, were the first to locate in Heward area. Of course, many more filed on homesteads that summer of 1900, but it was a very dry summer and there was very little hay to garner for their stock feed for winter and they did not come to prove up on their land till the spring of 1901. I was one of these, having written to the Land Department for an extension of time to get on my homestead, and I arrived in May 1901, driving from Crandall, Manitoba. I bought two fine horses and a wagon at Warden, Man. and drove across West to Cannington Manor, and the new village of Arcola, which was just 35 miles from my homestead, finally reaching Mr. Irvin and Mr. Caldwell's abode after seven full days trekking and over half of this distance only a faint trail.

These men gladly gave me shelter and Mr. Caldwell, next morning came with me to find the location of my farm which was four miles North West of theirs. I at once left for Arcola, our nearest village, for lumber for my house and stable. I made several trips to Arcola for lumber and food etc. before I could begin breaking the land and we had to ford Moose Mountain Creek, as there was no bridge and the water was very high at that time. In the summer of 1900, perhaps in May, William Tryon and Hamilton Caldwell filled homesteads 22-07-02, in this area on the Prairies. The two fellows met in Winnipeg on their way to take up land on the Prairies. Bill came from Owen Sound, Ont., and Hamilton from Central Island, B.C. While preparing to build their small house and a stable they got disgusted with the country, who had come to homestead too, but finally got used to it. They decided he would go back where he came from, but bought his horse and oxen outfit and started farming. They also bought a fine yoke of oxen from a farmer in the French Settlement near Mouse Mountain Creek.

Mr. McKenzie and wife and three children came too, that spring, he came from near Portage La Prairie and farmed a whole section a little south of where Heward now stands. Herb Fox and wife were the second couple to bring wives and George McCurry the third. Herb and wife came from Napinka, Man.; George and wife also came that spring coming in a covered wagon from Kansas, U.S.A., but they located about six miles North West. These people, as far as I can remember, homesteaded that summer of 1900, but of course many more followed. It was very little hay to carry for their stock feed for winter and they did not have enough prairie to the Land Department for an extension of time to get on my homestead and I arrived in May 1901 driving from Cranfill, Manitoba, and drove across West to Cranfill Manor, and the new settlement of Arcola, which was just 35 miles from my homestead, finally reaching Mr. Tryon and Mr. Caldwell's store after seven full days trekking and over half of this distance only a fair trail.

These men gladly gave me shelter and Mr. Caldwell, next morning came with me to find the location of my farm which was four miles North West of theirs. I let once left for Arcola, nearest village for Lumber and food. My house was stable. I made several trips to Arcola for lumber and food etc. before I could begin breaking the land and we had to ford Moore at that mouth of Mountrail Creek, as there was no bridge and the water was very high at that time. That spring and summer saw a great influx of people mostly bronco riders to our area, but naturally some women came in June and they were my closest neighbors, only two miles away and that was fine to have a good neighbor so close.

Our first Post Office was at Arcola, 25 miles away and in the French Settlement. In 1902 we had one at New Hope, only 12 miles away and in the farm house of William Carterov, any neighbor going for the mail always brought each other's mail and he also kept a General store there which was really appreciated by the settlers and we received mail once a week, usually someone went on Saturday for it.

The crops of 1901-02-3 had to be hauled to Arcola or Weyburn which is on the Soo Line, both about 95 miles away, but I had no crop till 1902. The price too, for wheat, was around $0.50 per bushel, not very remunerating but those days was really money.

The Canadian Pacific Railway surveyed the extension from Regina to Arcola in the fall of 1902; the first survey run through on corner of Ivy farm, but they made a second survey about a mile South, where they built
the line, in the summer of 1904. It came through Heward June 21st, 1904 and the track laying machine completed the line to Arcola July 15th and the ballasting was finished the middle of October the same year. Our wheat crop was shipped out that fall by loading on cars from the siding, and I'll say it was some job, but far superior to hauling it to Arcola or Weyburn, 35 miles, as we had been doing.

This extension of the railway, when built, was the longest, straightest railway in the world, over 100 miles as straight as surveyors could survey it. It had other special features too, for the grade up to the ties averaged only two feet, and the real grade of the railroad was only 1/10 of 1%, that is pretty level land.

In the summer of 1903 Phil Munro started up a store in a tent on Ham Caldwell's farm and soon George Docker and Kenneth Reid also a hardware and lumber store too, was started by Joseph Montjoy and Art Glover and a livery stable by Bob Adams. McDermaid and Reid had a general store at Caldwell's, but never moved to the site of Heward as the others did, but left for parts unknown. Billy Russell and Lort Williamson homesteaders christened the village CALDWELL in honor of the man who owned the land on which these stores were erected. They were all moved over to the site of the village the C. P. R. had surveyed nearby - HEWARD - in the spring of 1904. Tom Henderson on the way to New Hope April 6th or 6th 1904 was passing Phil Munro's store, Phil had his goods packed in boxes cut on the snow, ready to move to the new site Tom offered to move them for him and took them over to a stake set up by Phil on the new site on the snow, Tom dumped the load there and that was the first load of anything dumped on the Heward site. The other stores were moved over to the site by Billy Russell and Bob Adams, that day and the next. That summer Heward really grew, different stores grew up, implement dealers and others, we even had a newspaper edited by Robert Caskey, "THE HEWARD CHRONICLE", and our first postmaster was Richard Reilly and as he and his wife lived on the farm he had J. One of our homesteaders being over zealous thought we ought to have a flour mill at Heward, organized and sold stock for the same to us fellows. Well the mill was erected about 1906, but no machinery was installed and during the next summer in July it was wrecked by a tornado. In a tall building such as this was with very heavy timbers, there should have been double bracing from the cross timbers to the supporting posts, but they were absent. Harry Falconer who was standing in the livery stable doorway just South of the mill at that time of the tornado, saw it sway first to the east then west and finally east to the ground. I understand that Charlie Dempsey and his good wife built their residence in the village on the former mill site. A few months later the wreckage was auctioned off and brought $250.00 and a lot of us farmers had a good lesson.

Another fellow a year or so later organized and sold stock for the "Heward Steel and Wire Co." which included in it's charter the sale to farmers of about all the necessary articles a farmer required.

There were a car or two of fence posts came to Heward through it, then it was through and again we had another expensive lesson.

Homesteading 35 miles from a town Arcola for four years before a railway arrived and hauling grain that far to market was no easy task for any man or his horses. The hauling firewood from Moose Mountain 25 miles away or coal from Estevan 60 miles distant, though it only cost $1.75 per ton at the mines then, and the mosquitos during all the summer long, when we had to wear broad rimmed straw hats with netting over them, wearing gloves and the legs of an old sock for wristlets, even then we had plenty mosquito bites. The horses suffered too from them as soon as you unhitched them from the plow, at times they would roll with the harness on to get some relief from them. Luckily I had a sod roof on my stable keeping it cool thereby the mosquitos left the horses as soon as they entered the stable, enjoying the night in peace but had to face them again in the morning. When I now look back on what we got from this experience it really is something to remember. Later years there were no big prairie fires as the land became cultivated. Our houses were always open to help new comers and never locked while we were there. For instance, the trail North West ran very close to my gateway, to my pasture field, and one night was pretty dark and a traveller coming up the trail got into my pasture field, after going around the field a couple of times he again got out and made his way to my house, knocked, waked me up, and asked me the way to Jack Geddes place, I said you better feel your way along the wall and get in with me till morning for you will never find your way to his place this dark night, which he did.

Perhaps many of you who were farmers like myself and came early as settlers and homesteaders and have had some thoughts of the unfairness of the Government with us who bore the privation, loneliness and hardship and labor of early pioneers and got very little remuneration from our early day crops. Its true we got our homesteads for $10.00, but we stayed and put up with the hardships, improved our lands, which enhanced the neighbouring lands which we were not able to purchase, but the Government reserved all the Mineral rights for themselves. Its not every one that can shut himself up from the world as we did homesteading in the wilderness and take it and remain sane, and some did not. Of course at that time there was very little thought of what was under our feet and we walked around for a long time on top of a lot of money (oil) and did not know that it was there, but in the early fifties, really it was in January 15th, 1953 the "Tide Water Oil Co." drilled north of the village of Forget to 3,920 feet and struck the greatest oil well in Saskatchewan and the test officially established it produced 150 barrels an hour. The oil has 29.5 gravity and comes from the Madison formation of the Mississippi zone and the well is called Tide Water Forget Crown #1 in the Willison Basin area. The company capped the well.

Now the Government comes forth and tax us for the mineral rights if we hold any land taxable with those rights at 3 cents per acre per year and make those taxes retroactive back to 1945, and if not paid by May 1st they begin legal action to claim the oil rights for themselves, but this is not all either, they exonerate all the Canadian Pacific Railway who hold vast last acreage either side of their railways and all their town sites on the railways from any mineral tax of 3¢ per acre. Now we, the early settlers were the ones that made their lands increase in great value. Do you not think that this is unfair and can you ever forget the injustice of it?

He notified the neighbours and the Mounties who organized a general search by all of us neighbours. But no Frank could be found. When the snow began to melt in the early spring, Jack Pollok went out to get his cattle on evening, they were out on a little knoll where the snow had melted and there he found Frank's remains. He had waded through a heavy grass slough and did not get very far after that, he had wandered several miles with the storm. His moccasins which he had been wearing were found in a little pile he had been carrying when he left Walter's cabin. Dr. Roy Mustard who is living in Vancouver now was staying with his brother at the time, was the last person to see Frank Finn alive.

To Members and Friends,
The Convention of Baptist Churches,
British Columbia.

Dear Friends:

"Go in and possess the land" was the challenging theme of our last Convention and we hope that something of the thought and vision presented on that occasion has been passed on to all our churches, by the delegates who attended.

The maintenance and steady growth of each existing church is basic to the outreach of our denomination into new fields, and this aspect of our privilege and responsibility will call for continued loyalty to our own church, in prayer, regular attendance, service and financial support.

Recurring throughout the Convention meetings, however, was the expressed conviction, that, without lessening participation in the work of our own church, we must strengthen some of our weaker causes, helping them towards self-support, and in addition advance into new areas where opportunities are outstanding and needs are so urgent.

It is felt that qualified lay workers would be available in sufficient numbers for the establishment of Sunday School and Mission work as well as those ordained for the Ministry, when occasion required. In the consideration of this outreach however, a sense of frustration seems to recur when it is realized that our present Convention financial resources are quite inadequate to the requirement of an aggressive forward movement.

This gave rise to the suggestion that in addition to the stewardship of "giving" the question of stewardship in the use of money by way of "loan" might be considered, and your Board was instructed to survey this possibility.

As a result, a plan has been prepared and approved which calls for the setting up of what may be termed a Convention Investment Fund.

The suggested objective of the fund is $60,000. With such an amount available, a number of carefully selected and approved projects could be adequately launched, and with the impetus that could be expected from new causes well started, we could anticipate that in a minimum of time they would become self-supporting.

The Fund would be established from loans made by members and friends of our Convention. The loans would be repayable during ten years, an equal proportion being paid back each year, together with interest at 8 per cent. As an example, a person loaning $300 would at the end of the first year be repaid 1/10th of this amount, viz: $30 plus interest of $9. At the end of the second year another $30 would be repaid plus interest of $8.10 so that at the end of the 10th year the loan of $300 would have been repaid together with interest over the period amounting to $49.50.

We believe that there may be many persons who feel that they are sacrificially "giving" all that they consider possible, but who would be willing and able to "loan" some amount for investment in our Master's kingdom, being assured that at a stated date each year a proportion of the loan would be repaid with interest.

It is not contemplated that the total amount received in the Investment Fund would be used in outright gifts to new projects or causes requiring aid, but that at least 50% would be by way of loan to be subsequently repaid to the Fund. A proportion of the Fund would therefore be used on a revolving basis.

Guarantee for the repayment to those investing will be the responsibility of the whole Convention. Not less than one-tenth of the amounts initially subscribed will be held and invested in Government Bonds to secure repayment of Principal and interest for the first year. Subsequent amounts required for repayment will be included in the Convention Budget in addition to the amounts which in due course will return to the Fund on the revolving basis referred to above.

In order to determine the extent to which our friends will participate in this Investment Fund we are asking you to give earnest consideration to this proposed plan, and complete and return the attached memorandum.

You will note that if the sum you are prepared to loan is not immediately available, a date more convenient to you may be specified. The extent to which you participate in this Fund will be confidential to a small committee, and it would be greatly appreciated if with as little delay as possible you will complete and mail your response to the Secretary of the Board.

When you came to Dakota Territory the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?

No, I had no idea when I left for the West that I was going to stay there. I went because I heard so much about it from friends who had been there. These tales of the West intrigued me that the first chance I had to go West I would take it. This opportunity came the summer of 1893 when I was visiting my home. The trip was most interesting all the way for I had not taken any very distant trips until this one. When we came to the prairie it appealed to me for its vastness, and at once my mind went back to my school days and the beautiful poem we studied at school "THE PRAIRIES" by William Cullen Bryant, which explains the prairies so wonderfully. Read it if you have never done so! We de-trained at Griswold. Immediately it was threshing time and when I saw the amber wheat rolling out of the threshing machine by the thousands of bushels I said to myself I am going to do this too, that's when I make my decision to have a farm in the West. No homesteads to be taken up around the area I was now located in and I had to gather a little to start farming, so I worked at carpentry work for a couple of years. Then took up my homestead.
